The innovative cauldron ignition at the Beijing Winter Olympic Games opening ceremony delivered the idea of a shared, low-carbon future while incorporating Chinese philosophy, said the director of both the 2008 and 2022 Olympic opening and closing ceremonies, Zhang Yimou, in an interview with the China Media Group (CMG) on Friday. The 2022 Games opening ceremony was held on Friday night. The highly anticipated Olympic cauldron ignition was presented with modern technologies in an unprecedented way C no act of ignition, and a low fire instead of a blaze. "It is very simple and straightforward, but with a distinct idea - a 'micro fire' conveying the low-carbon and environment-friendly concept," said Zhang. #Beijing2022

On February 1, the Ugandan government announced its final investment decision that the Albert Lake oil field project has officially launched full-scale construction. The oil field is the first commercial oil discovery in Uganda, and China National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC) will work on the project. This marks another example of cooperation under the Belt and Road Initiative, Chen Zhuobiao, the CEO of CNOOC Uganda Branch, said, adding that the construction process and operation of the oil field will create more than 20,000 jobs in Uganda, and also boost training of local talent in the oil exploration sector.

Thirty-year-old Samuel Ikpefan will be the first cross-country skier in the history of Nigeria to compete in the Beijing Winter Olympics. After his first skiing experience at the age of six, he dreamed of becoming a professional skier. However, without funding, and without any natural snow in his country, he had to launch a crowd-funding campaign online to purchase equipment and arrange for his travel to other countries for training and competitions. Now, because of his participation, Nigeria, a country without snow, will have the opportunity to win a medal at #Beijing2022. "Nothing is impossible," said Ikpefan.收起

A video showing school officials in India closing the gates to keep out a group of young hijab-wearing students has gone viral, along with photos of reportedly Hindu boys in saffron scarves supporting the ban on the hijab. This comes as several schools in India have begun to bar girls in hijab from entering classrooms. The ban is being fought in court by a group of six teens as another group of girls are participating in a sit-in outside the school they are barred from entering because of their religious headscarf. Opponents to the ban say India's constitution guarantees everyone the right to practice their religion freely, and banning hijab is unconstitutional. Some politicians say all religious symbols should be kept out of schools and students should neither come wearing hijab or saffron shawls.#CGTNAmerica

India officially crossed 500,000 COVID-19 deaths on Friday, though experts believe that number was breached last year but was obscured due to inaccurate surveying and reporting. The country has had the fourth-highest tally of deaths globally, surpassing 400,000 deaths in July 2021 during the spike in Delta variant cases.Scientists in South Africa have made a copy of the Moderna COVID vaccine, in hopes of boosting vaccination rates across Africa.Moderna has said it would not enforce the patents on its vaccine, allowing scientists in Cape Town to make their own version of it.The company studying the new vaccine, Afrigen Biologics, says it hopes to start clinical trials in November.For Americans, Medicare, the federal health care insurance program for people aged 65 and over, will start paying for home COVID-19 tests at participating pharmacies and retailers.The Biden administration began requiring health insurers to cover costs of home tests for most Americans last month. Medicare was initially not included in the directive but was added after an outcry from seniors.South Korea has extended business curfews and social distancing rules on Friday for the next two weeks, amid soaring cases of the Omicron coronavirus variant. Restaurants, bars, and gyms will have to close shops at 9pm under this curfew.BA.2, the spinoff of the omicron variant of the coronavirus, has been detected in at least 49 countries, including the U.S.   #CGTNAmerica

General Kenneth McKenzie held a Pentagon briefing on Friday about an investigation into the Kabul airport attack that killed 13 U.S. service members last August.Officials presented the results of an investigation conducted on tactical, data, force posture, unit readiness and other readiness actions before, during, and after the attack. Officials say they concluded that the attack was a single blast, crossing fires created an illusion that there was a complex attack, but there were no gunshot wounds.  No evidence that any U.S. service members killed other service members or Afghans.#CGTNAmerica

The highest glacier on Mount Everest is melting at an alarming pace, according to a study by a University of Maine-led research team. #ChinaFaces: Gu Ailing looks forward to her performance in #Beijing2022Chinese freestyle skier Gu Ailing will compete in the women's freeski halfpipe, slopestyle and big air events in the Beijing 2022 Winter Olympic Games, which opens on Friday. Participating in three sports means a measure of pressure but is also a motivating force for the young athlete. "I am looking forward to my performance in the Winter Olympics," she said.After making a big splash at the 2020 Winter Youth Olympics, Gu has been learning new moves and bringing sliding skills to an even higher difficulty level. On February 7, she will make her 2022 Winter Olympics debut at the Shougang Ski Jumping Platform in west Beijing. She will then turn her attention to the women's freeski halfpipe and slopestyle events at Zhangjiakou City in neighboring Hebei Province on February 8."I love skiing, and it is a great honor for me to represent the Chinese team. I hope that my skiing experience can attract more young people to participate in this sport," Gu said.
China and Russia on Friday issued a joint statement.

The director of the World Health Organization said Wednesday that it’s premature for any country either to surrender, or to declare victory,” in the fight against COVID-19.The U.S. Army said Wednesday that it will begin removing soldiers who have refused to be vaccinated against COVID-19, in a move the Secretary of the Army described as necessary for Army readiness.  Malaysia began vaccinating children between five and 11 against COVID-19 on Thursday, kicking off its mass vaccination program for some of the youngest members of its population.  Europe could soon enter a COVID-19 “ceasefire” that could bring “enduring peace” Regional Director for Europe at the World Health Organization.  Although 12 million new cases were detected in Europe last week, officials have not seen a major spike in those requiring hospital care. Sweden and Denmark both announced the lifting of almost all COVID-19 restrictions this week.  New Zealand announced plans to reopen its borders in phases, signaling the country with some of the world’s toughest COVID-19 restrictions is beginning to ease measures.  Bangladesh is keeping its schools closed for two more weeks as COVID-19 cases continue to surge in the country.  The closures were set to lift on February 6.Chinese President Xi Jinping addressed the International Olympic Committee session in Beijing on Thursday and said “we will do our best to deliver a streamlined, safe and splendid Games,” one day before the Winter Olympics begin. There were 55 new COVID-19 infections detected among the Games-related staff on Wednesday.  All Games-related personnel are tested daily and reside within a closed loop system that keeps them isolated from the Chinese public. #CGTNAmerica

See the photos:The leader of #ISIS was killed during an overnight raid carried out by U.S. special forces in Syria’s northwestern #Idlib province, U.S. President Joe Biden said Thursday.The raid targeted Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi, who took over as head of the militant group on Oct. 31, 2019, just days after former leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi died during a U.S. raid in the same area. Biden said al-Qurayshi died as al-Baghdadi did, by exploding a bomb that killed himself and members of his family, including women and children, as U.S. forces approached. Aljazeera reported that a helicopter was seen hovering over the house for about two hours and fired five missiles, destroying the top level of the home. First responders reported that 13 people had been killed, including six children and four women.Al-Qurayshi was the suspected mastermind behind a recent deadly prison attack in northeastern #Syria, and the 2014 massacre of #Yazidis in #Iraq. A helicopter that took part in the raid suffered mechanical problems and was destroyed at a nearby landing site following the raid.#CGTNAmerica

CGTN reporters make their way to General Mountain Ski Resort in the region of Altay, to see the fast-moving silhouettes of skiers on the mountains and hear the area's ancient legends. The craft of making animal fur skis has been passed down through the generations, creating a legacy not just of athleticism, but also of perseverance. Jessica Zang收起

#ChinaFaces: Chinese content creator films 'dancing millet'Wang Xuefei, a young content creator from Aohan Banner of north China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, created some exquisite stop-motion animations using millet. The animation shows traditional Chinese dance and a handwritten Chinese character "福," which means "good fortune".Millet has a history of 8,000 years in Aohan, known as the "home of millet in the world.""I want to let more people know my hometown's millet," Wang said. "I watched a nice stop-motion animation recently and was inspired by it. So I decided to create my content by using this form."Wang said he plans to animate more traditional Chinese dances using millet, showcasing traditional culture in this entertaining way.Click the link to watch the animation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e8jtB9lt5Ww

#ChinaFaces: Meet the 'steel roses' who just won AFC Women's Asian Cup titleChina regained its glory at the 2022 Asian Football Confederation (AFC) Women's Asian Cup after winning the championship on Sunday C their first victory in 16 years. China defeated South Korea 3-2 at the DY Patil Stadium in Navi Mumbai, India. This is China's ninth Asian Cup trophy, the most among all teams."The championship significantly affirms our efforts," midfielder Wang Shanshan said. "It's a new beginning for the entire squad. We were in a downturn after the Tokyo 2020, but this time, we showed our real strength, solidarity and spirit."Despite initially trailing by two goals, China did not give up. The deficit made the "steel roses," as they're nicknamed at home, more determined and bolder."(Winning the championship) feels amazing, especially when I saw the fighting spirit inspired by the deficit," Head Coach Shui Qingxia said. "I'm very grateful to all the rosters who have overcome themselves in difficult situation and defeated the opponents."

Are you curious about the color scheme of this dance, or why the colors of the dancers' dresses stand out from the omnipresent China red? It's an unmistakable tribute to a special genre of Chinese fine art, the Blue and Green Landscape paintings, which originated in the Sui and Tang period and were revived in the Song Dynasty. The unique colors of azurite blue and malachite green come from precious minerals, rendering them an extravagance for Chinese artists as ultramarine blue was for Renaissance oil painters in the West. That's why this type of landscape paintings were mostly for the royal courts or wealthy families. One such painting was an 11.9-meter long scroll known as "A Panorama of Mountains and Rivers", projected on screens above and behind the dancers. It was painted around 900 years ago by an 18-year old genius painter for his Northern-Song emperor patron. Take a snapshot of any section of this painting and it's your dream screensaver. The painting "A Panorama of Mountains and Rivers" is now in the Palace Museum.You can see it here: https://www.dpm.org.cn/collection/paint/228354.htmll

#ChinaFaces: Malanhua Children's Choir sings the Olympic anthem in Greek during #Beijing2022 opening ceremonyDuring the opening ceremony of the Beijing 2022 Winter Olympics on February 4, a group of children attracted the attention of millions of viewers around the world. Dressed in clothes and shoes featuring a tiger image, they sang the Olympic anthem in Greek. This choir, named the Malanhua Children's Choir, is from Malan Village in north China's Hebei Province.How did these children from a small village make it to the grand stage of the opening ceremony? It's all thanks to Deng Xiaolan, a 78-year-old woman who founded the choir. Due to her personal experiences since childhood and her love for the village, she has always regarded this place as her "second hometown." After learning that children in Malan had lost the valuable opportunity to receive music education because of the village's remote location, she sought to change the situation.Following her retirement in 2004, Deng spent six months in Malan every year, voluntarily giving music classes to local children. With her earnest teaching, children learned to sing songs and play the violin. In 2006, Deng established the choir and led the children to perform in Beijing, Shanghai and many other big cities around China. This year, they performed at the Winter Olympics. Netizens commented that Deng had changed the village and children's lives with music. Now, the children have given back to the world with beautiful songs."A wonderful world outside the mountains is what children desire the most. I am happy to see that music makes them more optimistic and confident,"said Deng.

#ChinaFaces: Meet Chinese short-track speed skater Wu Dajing, who helped China win its first gold at #Beijing2022 "I've been through so much over the past four years, but I achieved my dream this time!" Chinese speed skater Wu Dajing said with tears in his eyes in a post-competition interview following Team China's golden start at the Beijing 2022 Olympic Winter Games on Saturday.Wu, together with teammates Fan Kexin, Qu Chunyu and Ren Ziwei, won #TeamChina's first gold medal at Beijing 2022 in the 2,000m short-track speed skating mixed relay with a time of 2 minutes and 37.348 seconds.It was the 27-year-old's second Olympic gold medal after winning at the 2018 Games in PyeongChang, where he became the first male Chinese skater to win an Olympic gold in short track, owing to his victory in the 500m event.Born in Jiamusi in northeast China's Heilongjiang Province, Wu has been in love with speed skating since childhood. After beginning professional training at the age of 10, he has always been a most dedicated athlete. "When he took off his stakes, sometimes the injuries to his feet glued his socks and skates together," recalled coach Li Jun, who added that the determined boy never missed a training session. Selected to the national team in 2010, Wu dedicated himself to improving his performances. In Sochi in 2014, he made his Olympic debut and won a silver medal in the 500m event.A core member of Team China, Wu still has two events to compete in: Men's 1000m and Men's 1000m relay. Stay tuned to CGTN for the latest from Beijing 2022!

Italy’s President Sergio Mattarella officially took office for a second term on Thursday after he was sworn in before a joint session of both Houses of Parliament. Mattarella attended a ceremony for his re-appointment at the Quirinale Presidential Palace in Rome, where he was greeted by an honour guard salute, before he made a speech.The 80-year-old was originally reluctant to spend another seven years as the country’s president but said that he was duty bound to accept the decision of parliament given the ongoing COVID-19 crisis and Italy’s current economic and social struggles.

More than 300 migratory whooper swans arrived at Manas National Wetland Park during the Spring Festival holiday from January 31 to February 6. Researchers identified one returning guest among the flock - a banded whooper swan with the serial number "1T11." Bird banding is a common practice for studying and identifying individual birds. Band number "1T11" has been spotted for nine consecutive years in the wetland in northwest China's Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region.收起

How long is a second? It’s a question most of us have never even really considered. But one that has captivated physicists for centuries not least because the most accurate answer to that question promises to reveal the deepest truths about the make-up of our universe. Jun Ye is a Chinese-American physicist and clockmaker extraordinaire at the University of Colorado, Boulder. He has built an optical lattice clock, a cloud of 100,000's of thousands of strontium atoms, which is inching closer to redefining the second. Ye's clock is so precise that it neither gains nor loses one second in some 15 billion years, roughly the age of the universe. History, inheritance of ice and snow culture in ChinaAs the #Beijing2022 Olympic Winter Games kicked off, people have paid greater attention to culture related to winter sports. Ice and snow culture in China dates back to a long time ago. Inheritance of and innovation in ice and snow culture in China crystalize the wisdom of harmonious relationship between human society and nature and embody the practical experience of the Chinese nation in understanding and utilizing nature.Petroglyph of skiers found in a cave in Altay city, northern edge of Junggar Basin, northwest China’s Xinjiang Uygur autonomous region, is so far one of the earliest records of humankind’s skiing activities.Skiing, as a means of transport for human beings in snowy mountains in winter, has a history of at least 10,000 years, as the petroglyph suggested.To survive cold winter, ancient Chinese people of various ethnic groups in northern China gradually turned ice and snow to their own advantage. For example, the ancients’ innovations for illumination in winter have evolved into today’s ice lanterns that people like watching so much.To strengthen defense, ancient Chinese people could build ramparts overnight by turning water into ice and then mixing it with earth. Moreover, they invented sledges so as to move faster when hunting in winter, and made use of ice and snow to store food to guarantee sufficient food supply in cold months. The tradition of food storage in winter has been followed to this day.As people’s needs for survival in winter were satisfied, ice and snow sports and art, which were oriented to recreation and relaxation, started to emerge. According to historical records, skating was a verified ancient ice and snow recreational activity. During the reign of Emperor Qianlong (1736 - 1796) of the Qing dynasty, ice and snow sports became quite popular, and a series of activities on ice, including skating, ice skate archery and rolling on ice, took shape, which involved early forms of skates and sledges.In modern times, Chinese people began to add different colors to the colorless ice and white snow by developing environment-friendly pigments, and decorate urban areas in northern China with ice lanterns and ice and snow sculptures, expanding ice and snow application scenarios.The first Harbin Ice Lantern Garden Party held in Harbin city, northeast China’s Heilongjiang province, in 1963, effectively fueled the emergence of ice and snow art in various regions across China.In Shenzhen, south China’s Guangdong province, people have built low-temperature winter sports venues with air domes, where the all-white structures and snowmakers and other facilities inside simulate realistic indoor ice and snow sports fields. Wenzhou city, east China’s Zhejiang province, has established scenario-based indoor ski centers and ice and snow theme parks, breaking the geography and season limits of ice and snow sports and culture.The designs of venues for the 2022 Olympic Winter Games represent creative transformation of ice and snow elements. The National Ski Jumping Center in Zhangjiakou city, north China’s Hebei province, one of the venues, features an S-shaped curve which resembles a jade Ruyi scepter, a Chinese talisman. The design is expected to convey good wishes.In the digital era, virtual reality (VR), digital twin, virtual studio and other technologies are widely adopted in the culture sector, allowing ice and snow culture to further break the restrictions of season and transformation and be inherited in new ways.With the help of a 360-degree camera that captures panoramic images of ice and snow and a VR helmet equipped with locator and supporting different angles, users can experience the fun of being in a world of ice and snow. Injury-free ski training, which features the combination of VR headsets and indoor ski training equipment, has benefited an increasing number of winter sports enthusiasts.The ongoing Beijing 2022 Olympic Winter Games have employed digital technologies for broadcasting, which effectively enrich the experience of the audience.One of the new explorations in the innovative development of ice and snow culture is reproducing ice and snow figures in ancient artworks or creating virtual ice and snow figures via digital technologies.Thanks to the digital transformation of an ancient painting depicting a grand skating event over 200 years ago, more than 1,000 figures in the painting seem to have been brought back to life and a large-scale on-ice competition in ancient times has been vividly reproduced.An online video introduced by China Mobile, which is based on the story of Chinese freestyle skier Gu Ailing, has successfully created the image of a virtual winter sports athlete.In its integration with digital technologies, ice and snow culture has embraced further development and transformation, during which people’s experiences of the culture have also been constantly enriched. (By Liao Dan)

What did Eileen Gu do on the night before she scored her 1st gold medal in Winter Olympics? She slammed Insider, a media company, on Instagram for misleading portrayal about Chinese towards figure skater Zhu Yi. Zhu Yi was another US-born olympian who competed for China. The article claimed that Chinese attacked her for not getting a gold medal, ignoring most of people just want them to be happy and safe after facing pressure over backlash for representing China instead of U.S. Analysts expected Gu for a bronze in Big Air but Gu broke her record with her 1st gold medal. Gu told the media that she was not “trying to keep everyone happy” but wanted to promote understanding between nations and pushing human limits beyond nationalities through skiing. #UnityIsStrength #womeninsports #peaceonearth##WinterOlympics2022 #Beijing2022 #skiing #skating

“We would live very well without Facebook” - France’s Finance Minister, Bruno Le Maire, took aim at Meta after the tech company warned that without adequate agreements to transfer data between the EU and U.S., it could suspend “Facebook and Instagram in Europe.” Le Maire was echoed by his German counterpart Robert Habeck, who told reporters: “After being hacked, I’ve lived without Facebook and Twitter for four years, and life has been fantastic.” "We have absolutely no desire and no plans to withdraw from Europe, but the simple reality is that Meta, and many other businesses, organizations, and services, rely on data transfers between the EU and the U.S. in order to operate global services," Meta stated in an annual report to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Even for an indoor sport like curling, the weather still matters. In fact, curling has strict requirements for temperature and humidity. Weather conditions, such as rain and snow, and even the presence of spectators at the venue can affect temperature and humidity levels inside the venue, thereby influencing the coefficient of friction between the stone and ice and thus affecting performance. #ChinaFaces: Meet Chinese speed skater Ren Ziwei, who won China's second gold at #Beijing2022 "The short track speed skating team will never let people down. That is a tradition," Chinese speed skater Ren Ziwei said in a post-competition interview following his first individual Olympic gold medal at the Beijing 2022 Olympic Winter Games on Monday.The 24-year-old finished first in the men's 1000m final with one minute and 26.768 seconds, winning China's second gold at the 2022 Games after their victory in the 2000m mixed team relay on Saturday.Born in northeast China's Harbin, which is also known as "the city of ice," Ren began speed skating training early and joined the city's professional team when he was 8 years old. Influenced by his father, an army veteran, Ren possessed great determination and tenacity as an athlete. "I regard sports as the battlefield in a peaceful era, and I will fight like a soldier in each game."Recruited into the national team in 2014, Ren made fast progress and bagged a silver medal in men's 5000m relay four years later in his Olympic debut at PyeongChang. A "rising star" of #TeamChina, Ren will also compete in men's 1500m on Wednesday. Stay tuned to CGTN for the latest from Beijing 2022!

Eighty-Six percent of people living in urban areas are being exposed to a dangerous amount of air pollution, according to research newly published in The Lancet Planetary Health journal.Around 2.5 billion people are being exposed to air pollution levels roughly seven times greater than guidelines put out by the World Health Organization. According to the data taken from 13,000 cities, researchers attributed 1.8 million deaths in 2019 to these unhealthy levels of urban air pollution.

More than 300 migratory whooper swans arrived at Manas National Wetland Park during the Spring Festival holiday from January 31 to February 6. Researchers identified one returning guest among the flock - a banded whooper swan with the serial number "1T11." Bird banding is a common practice for studying and identifying individual birds. Band number "1T11" has been spotted for nine consecutive years in the wetland in northwest China's Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region.

Are you curious about the color scheme of this dance, or why the colors of the dancers' dresses stand out from the omnipresent China red?  It's an unmistakable tribute to a special genre of Chinese fine art, the Blue and Green Landscape paintings, which originated in the Sui and Tang period and were revived in the Song Dynasty. The unique colors of azurite blue and malachite green come from precious minerals, rendering them an extravagance for Chinese artists as ultramarine blue was for Renaissance oil painters in the West. That's why this type of landscape paintings were mostly for the royal courts or wealthy families.One such painting was an 11.9-meter long scroll known as "A Panorama of Mountains and Rivers", projected on screens above and behind the dancers. It was painted around 900 years ago by an 18-year old genius painter for his Northern-Song emperor patron. Take a snapshot of any section of this painting and it's your dream screensaver. The painting "A Panorama of Mountains and Rivers" is now in the Palace Museum. #CMG2022SpringFestivalGala #ChineseNewYearFor more: https://bit.ly/3Go2AIh收起

How long is a second? It’s a question most of us have never even really considered. But one that has captivated physicists for centuries not least because the most accurate answer to that question promises to reveal the deepest truths about the make-up of our universe. Jun Ye is a Chinese-American physicist and clockmaker extraordinaire at the University of Colorado, Boulder. He has built an optical lattice clock, a cloud of 100,000's of thousands of strontium atoms, which is inching closer to redefining the second. Ye's clock is so precise that it neither gains nor loses one second in some 15 billion years, roughly the age of the universe. Xiao Wei, who has been a psychological counselor for nine years, said that isolation or limitations on movement make people prone to anxieties and constraints, as they have limited interactions, whether it's in neighborhoods or other circumstances. It’s estimated we’ll need to upskill or reskill at least 85 million people by 2030 to prevent the global economy losing more than $8 trillion in GDP, as a result of artificial intelligence, automation, changing demographics and globalisation.That’s got the world of business, politics and education talking - or better still, thinking. So, this week on The Agenda, Stephen Cole finds out why Critical Thinking is such a sought-after skill, how it’s being taught in education, whether politicians are applying it enough and learns who are most likely to become the thinkers of the future.Opening the show, Salah Khalil - Director of Macat International - joins Stephen to explain the overall concept of critical thinking and why it’s increasingly adopted by businesses to help humans compete with the machines of the future.Lord Jim Knight joins the conversation to express how important it is for academia not to overlook the potential of using play-based learning as way of fostering critical thinking, which he says can significantly improve productivity in all areas of our lives.And closing the show is Anthony McClaran, Vice-Chancellor of St. Mary's University in London. Anthony tells Stephen why critical thinking has been adopted as part of their curriculum, and why the use of social media by students is often a background barrier to their teaching efforts.Learn more on #TheAgenda at: https://www.cgtn.com/europe/the-agenda 收起请访问新冠疫情信息中心了解疫苗相关资源。了解疫苗信息

Calendar for Spring Festival: Lantern FestivalThe #LanternFestival, or #Yuanxiao Festival, falls on the 15th day of the first lunar month, this year, on February 15. With a history of more than 2,000 years, the Lantern Festival is a traditional folk festival, but also as an important occasion for #family #reunions, for family members to get together, savor delicious food and enjoy festive folk-art performances.As the name suggests, lanterns will be hung out for the festival. The lanterns represent wishes for a bright future. Traditionally, the lanterns are red, an auspicious color in Chinese culture. Nowadays, however, lanterns are made in a variety of colors and forms, with the auspicious Chinese elements such as zodiac signs, lotus, dragons, and phoenix being favored design choices. During the evening, with all the bulbs turned on, the lantern fairs look as bright as they would during the daytime.Lantern Festival is also called “Yuanxiao Festival” because people usually eat Yuanxiao or Tangyuan, a glutinous rice ball usually filled with sweet fillings such as red bean paste, sesame paste, or peanut butter during the festival. People believe that the round shape of the ball and its sweet fillings symbolize family unity, completeness, and happiness for the entire year.收起

Russia says military drills in Crimea have ended, and that troops were returning to their permanent base. State television broadcast footage showing military units crossing a bridge linking the Russia-controlled peninsula to the mainland. It comes a day after Moscow said it was pulling back some of the troops it had deployed near its neighbor's borders. Following talks with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, Russian President Vladimir Putin stressed he did not want war over #Ukraine amid Western fears it would invade the former Soviet republic. Western leaders remain unconvinced by Moscow's move, however. U.S. President Joe Biden said #Russia could still launch an attack.收起

Some elderly inhabitants of the ancient city of Beijing have developed a tradition of visiting the Temple of Heaven every day at the crack of dawn. They wake up before the sun rises and head out with almost prayer-like devotion after a humble but warm breakfast. They meet friends, practice Tai Chi, learn group dances, play musical instruments and connect with fellow early birds. Have a look at their activities for a unique insight into the youthful spirit that powers this dual-Olympic city.收起
